title: HellermannTyton surges on Delphi Automotive takeover
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Jul 30, 2015, 19:48 BST - UK Markets closed HellermannTyton surges on Delphi Automotive takeover By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 35 minutes ago 414.00 -3.60 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in HellermannTyton posted their biggest ever one-day jump after Delphi Automotive said it would buy the company. 
Shares in cabling products maker HellermannTyton posted their biggest ever one-day jump on Thursday, after New York-listed Delphi Automotive (NYSE: DLPH - news ) said it would buy the company. 
The deal, which is valued at around £1.1bn, will help Delphi enhance its product portfolio, most notably its electrical architecture business. 
Delphi will pay 480p in cash for each HellermannTyton share, representing a significant premium to its closing price on Wednesday of 332.1p. Although 75pc of shareholders still need to back the deal, analysts are confident it will proceed, and have described the premium as “justified”. 
Management intend to recommend unanimously that shareholders vote in favour of the takeover offer at its general meeting, which will be held before the end of the year.Analysts at Berenberg noted Delphi’s successful track record of integrating businesses, and believe the company can realise $50m per year in synergies by the end of 2018. 
The transaction lifted HellermannTyton’s 138.4p, or 41.7pc, to 470.5p. 
On the broader market, another set of strong corporate earnings helped Britain’s benchmark index hit a one-week high, despite concerns over slowing growth in China. The FTSE 100 advanced 37.87 points to 6,668.87. * Chinese stocks close down after sudden drop Royal Dutch Shell (Xetra: R6C1.DE - news ) was among the FTSE favourites after it posted better-than-anticipated second-quarter results. The oil giant also revealed plans to axe 6,500 jobs as part of its cost-cutting measures and dispose of assets worth around $50bn in the next three years. Despite the depressed oil price, Shell (LSE: RDSB.L - news ) said its takeover of BG Group (LSE: BG.L - news ) remained on track. Shares in both companies rallied, with Shell’s “B” shares up 42.7pc to £18.61 and BG adding 3.8pc to £10.79. 
Meanwhile, the long-standing speculation of a tie-up between InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) and Starwood gained fresh momentum yesterday after reports suggested the pair had held talks. FTSE 100-listed IHG denied the rumours after markets closed and its shares had risen 120p, or 4.6pc, to £27.43. 
IHG also reported half-year operating profit of $337m , a 9pc rise on the previous year. 
Elsewhere, AstraZeneca (NYSE: AZN - news ) became the latest pharmaceutical company to beat market expectations , sending the stock 128.5p higher to £43.19. 
The drug maker posted a smaller-than-anticipated fall in revenue of 7pc in the second quarter, thanks to the strong dollar and a good performance from its diabetes franchise. 
Returning to the mid-cap index, electronic components maker Laird (Other OTC: LARRF - news ) leapt 50.3p, or 14.4pc, to 400.1p after it reported robust half-year results. The group, which counts Apple (NasdaqGS: AAPL - news ) and Samsung among its customers, saw pre-tax profits jump by 35pc, boosted by the performance in its materials and wireless divisions. 
Premier Farnell (LSE: PFL.L - news ) nursed further losses, recording its worst two-day loss in four years, as brokers slashed its target price following Wednesday’s unexpected profit warning. 
Numis, RBC Capital Markets and Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) all cut their recommendations as Raspberry Pi sales slowed at the electronics specialist. Julian Cater, of Numis, reckons the operational review announced on Wednesday will lead to a reduction in the number of distribution centres, and see the business withdraw from some geographic markets. 
Premier Farnell’s shares fell 4.1pc to 134.2p, after dropping 16pc on Wednesday. 
Countrywide (Other OTC: CTYWY - news ) also fell into negative territory, suffering its biggest one-day drop in two years, as half-year pre-tax profits slumped 22pc due to political uncertainty prior to the general election. 
Britain’s largest estate agency warned the near-term will “remain challenging” after home sales dropped by 12pc in the first six months of the year. 
Although analysts pointed to a better outlook for the second-half of the year, Keith Baird, of Panmure Gordon, warned “affordability is an increasing issue” in the housing market. Countrywide’s stock lost 22p, or 4pc, to close at 531p. 
Babcock International (LSE: BAB.L - news ) became the biggest FTSE 100 faller - down 53.5p to 985.5p - after it warned revenue from oil and gas would be lower in the first half of the year. Christopher Bamberry, of Peel Hunt, noted the “shares have been de-rated over the past 15 months because of concerns about the potential impact from the falling oil price”. 
Finally, Aim-listed Accesso surged 25.7pc to 672.5p after it secured a seven-year deal with Merlin Entertainments (LSE: MERL.L - news ) to provide the accesso Passport ticketing system across the full Merlin estate.
